tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
a song no one has ever sung before. See how this is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:096:001|96:1]].

tn.ref: his right hand and his holy arm have
tn.text: The words "right hand" and "holy arm" refer to Yahweh's strength. Together they emphasize how great his strength is. AT: "his very great power has" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])
the more powerful and skilled hand
Here "arm" is a metonym for power. AT: "the power that is his alone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Possible meanings are 1) "enabled him to defeat his enemies" or 2) "enabled him to save his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The abstract noun "salvation" can be translated using the verb "save." AT: "showed people that he saves his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

tn.ref: showed his justice to all the nations
tn.text: The abstract noun "justice" can be translated using the adjective "just." The word "nations" is a metonym for "the people who live in all the nations." AT: "showed the people who live in all the nations that he is just" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"remembers." See how "call to mind" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:020:003|20:3]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: all the ends of the earth ... all the earth
tn.text: These are metonyms for the people of the earth. AT: "people from all over the world ... all people in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: will see the victory of our God
tn.text: The abstract noun "victory" can be translated using the verb "defeat." AT: "will see our God defeat his enemies" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
"suddenly begin singing happily"
"sing because you are happy"
"sing praises to God"
delightful or pleasing musical sound
an animal horn used as a musical instrument
"raise a shout." See how "shout" is translated in [[:en:bible:notes:psa:047:001|47:1]].

tn.ref: Let the sea shout and everything in it
tn.text: The psalmist speaks as if the sea were a person who could shout to God. AT: "Let it be as if the sea and everything in it shout" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: the world and those who live in it
tn.text: The psalmist speaks as if the world were a person. AT: "and let the world and those who live in it shout" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Let the rivers clap their hands, and let the mountains shout for joy
tn.text: The psalmist speaks as if the rivers and mountains were people who could clap and shout. AT: "Let it be as though the rivers are clapping their hands and mountains were shouting for joy" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])
These phrases are metonyms for "the people in the world" and "the people who live in the nations." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"he will judge the nations with fairness" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"honestly" or "using the same standard for everyone"
